awd_titl_txt: Technology as Sovereignty: Open Hardware Politics and New Property Relations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine how citizens, including engineers and policy makers, understand and pursue “technological sovereignty” today. Since the COVID-19 pandemic global supply chain breakdown, various governments have established domestic high-tech supply chains policies as part of their sovereignty agendas. To better understand the political effects of these emergent constructions of technology as sovereignty, this project will examine how these claims affect technology production regimes and the property relations. This research benefits policy makers interested in technology, trade, and manufacturing policies and their impact on industry and well-being. This research also benefits designers and technologists engaged in innovative manufacturing practices by showing how policy affects innovative capacity. Findings from this project will provide the ground for developing a workshop to bring policymakers' and developers’ attention to the ethical dimension of component procurement and labor sourcing in technology production.

This project examines technological sovereignty and its varied impacts on workers, engineers, and citizens via the study of open hardware practices. It uses qualitative methods, including ethnographic observations, archival research, and semi-structured interviews. Ethnographic observations at electronic workers’ organizations and open hardware firms will show how technological sovereignty affects and is created through open hardware practices. Archival research at institutional archives will help track changes in these constructions over time. Ethnographic and archival data will be supplemented by interviews with key stakeholders on motivations, justifications, tensions, and contradictions surrounding open hardware . Finally, this project will digitize electronic manufacturing workers' archives, contributing to their organizing practices toward more ethical supply chains.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined how citizens, including engineers and policy makers, understand and pursue “technological sovereignty” today. Since the COVID-19 pandemic global supply chain breakdown, various governments have established domestic high-tech supply chains policies as part of their sovereignty agendas. To better understand the political effects of these emergent constructions of technology as sovereignty, this project examined how these claims affect technology production regimes and their property relations.

To do this, this project studied the category “technological sovereignty” and its varied impacts on workers, engineers, and citizens via the study of open hardware practices. It used qualitative methods, including ethnographic observations, archival research, and semi-structured interviews. Ethnographic observations at electronic workers’ organizations and open hardware firms will show how technological sovereignty affects and is created through open hardware practices. Archival research at institutional archives helped track changes in these constructions over time. Ethnographic and archival data will be supplemented by interviews with key stakeholders on motivations, justifications, tensions, and contradictions surrounding open hardware . Finally, this project will digitize electronic manufacturing workers' archives, contributing to their organizing practices toward more ethical supply chains.

Data collected on this topic revealed that stakeholders attached different meanings to  the term “technological sovereignty” Such meanings shape and are shaped by the organization of  computing’s global supply chains. For example, the 2020 semiconductor shortage led to the reorganization of the supply chain. To navigate this new organization, designers articulated new technology procurement practices to navigate such scarcity. These practices are increasingly identified as working towards “technological sovereignty.” 

These research  findings benefited policy makers interested in technology, trade, and manufacturing policies and their impact on industry. It  also benefited designers and technologists engaged in innovative manufacturing practices by showing how policy affects innovative capacity.  Findings from this project provided the ground for developing three presentations to bring for hardware developers’ attention to the ethical dimension of component procurement and labor sourcing in technology production. The author published some of the outcomes of this work in a journal and  presented it in four conferences. These audiences include designers, social scientists, computer scientists, and policy researchers.

 

Publication:

Uribe del Águila, Verónica. "Making Innovation in the Mexican Silicon Valley: The Early Years of El Centro de Tecnología de Semiconductores (1981-2001)." IEEE Annals of the History of Computing (2024).

https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/10505762 

 

Conferences

Business History Conference (BHC) 2024 | "Doing Business in the Public Interest" (Providence, Rhode Island, USA, March 14th-16th) Panel: “Localized Strategies of Small Electronics Businesses in the Americas (1970s-1980s),” Presentation: “Making Innovation in the Mexican Silicon Valley: The Early Years of El Centro de Tecnología de Semiconductores (1981-2001)” (participant) 

 

AAA 2023 | Transitions (Toronto, Canada, November 15-19) Roundtable: “Technologies from the South as Method and Challenge” 

 

SHOT 2023 | Annual Meeting (Long Beach, California, USA, October 26-29) Panel: “Reverse engineering is society made legible,” Presentation: “Reverse Engineering within Import Substitution (ISI) Models of Development: The Mexican Computer Program (1979-1990)” (co-organizer and participant) 

 

SSRC Data Fluencies Project Research Development Workshop 2023 | Labor and Technology (Simon Fraser University, Vancouver, Canada, July 24-25) (participant).
